verses.text: On my bed during the nights, I searched for the one whom my soul loves. I sought him, but I did not find him.
verses.comment: The opening verse vividly expresses yearning and spiritual longing, echoing the soul’s search for God. The idea of seeking but not finding parallels passages about seeking God wholeheartedly. Traditional interpretation sees this as an allegory for the soul’s quest for union with the divine.

verses.text: I will rise now and go around the city, through the streets and the squares; I will seek the one whom my soul loves. I searched for him, but I did not find him.
verses.comment: The movement from private yearning to public searching emphasizes persistence in spiritual pursuit. This can be viewed as the believer’s active participation in seeking truth and love beyond mere feeling, resonating with the idea of pilgrimage and journey towards spiritual fulfillment.

verses.text: The watchmen found me as they went around the city. I asked, 'Have you seen the one whom my soul loves?'
verses.comment: Watchmen may symbolize spiritual guides or leaders. The reliance on those who keep vigil hints at the importance of authority, wisdom, and guidance in pursuing genuine love and understanding, subtly pointing toward the necessity of visible leadership in the life of faith. Compare with seeking counsel in Proverbs.

verses.text: Hardly had I passed them when I found the one whom my soul loves. I held him and would not let him go until I had brought him into my mother's house, into the room of her who conceived me.
verses.comment: The beloved’s embrace and bringing him home suggest the joy of union in intimacy and faith. Some spiritual interpretations see the ‘mother’s house’ as the place where faith is nurtured—hinting at the importance of spiritual tradition and continuity. Christological parallels echo Mary Magdalene’s encounter with the risen Christ (John 20:17).

verses.text: I charge you, daughters of Jerusalem, by the gazelles and the does of the field: do not arouse or awaken love until it so desires.
verses.comment: A repeated refrain, calling for patience regarding love’s fulfillment. This signifies discipline and respect for the timing of spiritual commitments, which also invites reflection on the proper order of spiritual life and practices.

verses.text: Who is this coming up from the wilderness like pillars of smoke, perfumed with myrrh and frankincense, with all the fragrant powders of the merchant?
verses.comment: The imagery of smoke, perfume, myrrh, and frankincense recalls royal and priestly associations. These elements also appear at Christ’s birth and burial, suggesting this figure represents both divine and human aspects and evokes the sacrificial offering and worship motifs.

verses.text: Look! It is Solomon’s carriage, surrounded by sixty mighty men, the elite of Israel.
verses.comment: Solomon’s carriage is a symbol of majesty, order, and protection, guarded by chosen men. The mention of a king’s retinue may carry nuances about the organization and authority gifted to the people of God, suggesting visible structures and leadership are essential to the spiritual journey.

verses.text: All of them are skilled with the sword, trained for battle, each with his sword at his side, prepared against the terrors of the night.
verses.comment: Defenders equipped with swords hint at spiritual warfare, paralleling the call to stand firm and don the armor of God. The vigilance against nightly fears reflects the necessity for spiritual preparedness and protection against temptation and evil.

verses.text: King Solomon made himself a carriage from the wood of Lebanon.
verses.comment: Lebanon’s timber was used in the temple and palace, connecting royal glory with divine worship. The use of precious material for Solomon’s carriage suggests the significance of beauty and excellence in offering oneself in worship—a subtle nod to the value of tangible expressions of faith and reverence.

verses.text: He made its posts of silver, its back of gold, its seat of purple; inside it is lovingly inlaid by the daughters of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Descriptions of gold, silver, purple—colors and materials associated with kingship and liturgy—suggest both majesty and the role of the people in preparing something beautiful for the beloved. It also evokes communal worship and honoring and points to the importance of ritual and liturgical beauty in the spiritual life.

verses.text: Go out, daughters of Zion, and look upon King Solomon, with the crown with which his mother crowned him on the day of his wedding, on the day of the joy of his heart.
verses.comment: The crowning at the wedding illustrates the union between king and bride, with deep messianic echoes—anticipating Christ as the Bridegroom. The reference to the mother’s role amplifies the honor bestowed and points to the importance of tradition in conferring dignity in spiritual and communal life. Compare with the prophetic vision of God rejoicing over his people like a bridegroom (Isaiah 62:5).
